fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a simplicial group, we can define a model of its universal principal bundle \mathbf {E} G \to \mathbf {B} G as simplicial sets W G \to \bar {W} G. This is a generalization of the bar construction, if we consider a group G as a discrete simplicial set. It classifies principal G-bundles in the sense of Theorem 21.13 in Simplicial objects in algebraic topology.

We define the n-simplices of W G to be (W G)_n = G_0 \times G_1 \times \cdots \times G_n so that G_n acts on (W G)_n by taking the face map that discards the last k vertices for each k, and then acting on the appropriate factor on the right. This forces the face maps and degeneracy maps to be \begin {aligned} \partial _k (g_0, \dots , g_n) &= (g_0, \dots , g_{k-1}, \partial _k g_{k+1}, \dots , \partial _k g_n), \\ \sigma _k (g_0, \dots , g_n) &= (g_0, \dots , g_{k}, \sigma _k g_{k}, \dots , \sigma _k g_n). \end {aligned} We define \bar {W} G to be W G quotiented by the action of G. This can be represented as (\bar {W} G)_n = G_0 \times \cdots \times G_{n-1}, with the quotient map (W G)_n \twoheadrightarrow (\bar {W} G)_n given by (g_0, \dots , g_n) \mapsto (g_0 (\partial _1 g_1)^{-1}, \dots , g_{n-1} (\partial _n g_n)^{-1}). The face and degeneracy maps can then be computed to be \begin {aligned} \partial _k (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{k-1} \cdot \partial _k g_k, \partial _k g_{k+1}, \dots , \partial _k g_{n-1}), \\ \partial _n (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{n-2}) \\ \sigma _k (g_0, \dots , g_{n-1}) &= (g_0, g_1, \dots , g_{k-1}, 1, \sigma _k g_{k}, \dots , \sigma _k g_{n-1}). \end {aligned} A quick computation shows that this indeed produces a simplicial principal fiber bundle with fiber G.
A copy of the book can be found at https://ncatlab.org/nlab/files/May_SimplicialObjectsInAlgebraicTopology.pdf.

fr:title.text: Abelian group structure on the W-bar construction

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Abelian group structure on the W-bar construction

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Suppose the simplicial group G is abelian, then the W-bar construction still has an abelian group structure, by multiplication element-wise.

Given a simplicial set B, a simplicial group G with a twisting function \tau , the twisted product is the pullback B \times _{\bar {W} G} W G with the W-bar construction. We write B \times _\tau G so as to make explicit the twisting function. This is a simplicial principal fiber bundle.

More explicitly, we define B \times _\tau G to be the same as the Cartesian product B \times G, but with one face map altered. The pair (b, g) represents the element in B \times _{\bar {W} G} W G whose first component is b \in B, and the second component is (g_0, \dots , g_n) \in W G, where each element is an iterated product \begin {aligned} g_n &= g \\ g_{k-1} &= \tau (\partial _{k+1} \cdots \partial _n b) \cdot (\partial _{k} g_{k}). \end {aligned} This forces the last face map to be \partial _n (b, g) = (\partial _n b, \tau (b) \cdot \partial _n g), and the other face and degeneracy maps are unchanged.

Given a simplicial group G, a twisting function on a simplicial set B is a simplicial map B \to \bar {W} G to the W-bar construction. It represents a cocycle valued in G. Recall that (\bar {W} G)_n = G_0 \times \cdots \times G_{n-1}. Taking the face map \partial _{n} reveals that all but the last component of the map B_n \to (\bar {W} G)_n are determined by the lower dimension maps. Hence we can obtain a more minimalistic combinatorial description.

This is a set of notes on effective homology and algebraic topology. Main references are Constructive Homological Algebra and Applications and Discrete Vector Fields and Fundamental Algebraic Topology. We assume basic familiarity with the classical aspects of the theory, although there will also be links within this forest to the relevant concepts.

fr:ul.fr:li: W-bar construction, simplicial principal bundles, twisted products by Simplicial objects in algebraic topology
composition of strong homology equivalence, tensor product, cone, bicomplex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given a simplicial group G, a fiber bundle p : E \to B is principal if G acts on the fibers freely and transitively on the right. This condition can be checked in each dimension separately.

Given any group G, we can construct a model of the first Eilenberg–MacLane space K(G, 1) as a simplicial set \bar {W}(G). Consider the contractible simplicial set W(G) whose set of n-simplices is given by G^{n+1}. This has a natural free G-action given by multiplying every entry on the left. \bar {W}(G) is constructed by the quotient of the G-action.

More concretely, the n-simplices are given by n-tuples, representing the quotient of consecutive elements in the (n+1)-tuple in the unquotiented simplicial set above. This is traditionally written as a bracketed sequence of elements separated by bars, [g_1 \mid g_2 \mid \dots \mid g_n], hence we name it the bar construction. Face maps are given by removing the corresponding bars so the elements multiply together. Degeneracy maps are given by inserting the identity elements.
If the group has decidable equality and multiplication, then the simplicial set is also effective. If further more the group is computably finite, then it is of finite type.
